Dear Jason M Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001496
Special Investigation Intake Date: June 10, 2024
License #: CI410201226
Licensee Group Organization: Wedgwood Christian Services
Licensee Designee: David Gorman
Chief Administrator: Jason M Lheureux
Agency Name: KENTWOOD CAMPUS
Agency Address: 3290 36TH ST
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49512-8193
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 03/01/2025
Capacity: 36
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/6/24, a staff was in a small conference room with 3 youth.
Two youth pulled down the third youth's pants and underwear and
began laughing at the youth. Staff was present and did not
intervene.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on June 10, 2024.
Complainant reported Youth A disclosed this information on June 7,
2024, and the incident occurred on June 6, 2024. She reported
Supervisor would have more information. Complainant reported she
was concerned about Staff 1 not intervening on the situation or
reporting the situation.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 10,
2024. Youth A reported on June 6, 2024, he was playing board
games in the side room with Youth B and Youth C. He stated Staff 1
was the only staff within the room supervising them. Youth A
reported when Youth A looked out the window with his back turned,
Youth B came up to him and pulled down his pants. He reported his
pants were only down for a few second and Youth B did this to bully
him. Youth A reported Youth C was laughing at him and attempted to
try to keep Youth A’s hands down so he could not pull his pants back
up. He reported he was able to get his hands free and does not know
why this happened. Youth A reported Staff 1 was sitting in a chair
when this occurred and did nothing to intervene on the situation. He
denied Staff 1 said anything to Youth B or Youth C about the
situation. Youth A reported Youth B and Youth C also tried to stuff his
jacket in the ceiling tile in the room. He reported after that occurred,
Staff 1 had the youth leave the side room. Youth A reported he told
Supervisor about this situation the next day.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed separately face to face at
the facility on June 10, 2024. Youth B and Youth C both denied
anything occurred on June 6, 2024. Both the youth refused to talk
2

about the situation and noted they have no concerns with Staff 1’s
ability to keep them safe. Youth B and Youth C both ended the
interviews early as they did not want to speak to this consultant.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 10,
2024. Staff 1 reported on June 6, 2024, he brought Youth A, Youth B,
and Youth C into one of side rooms to play board games. He
reported Youth A was trying to play around with Youth B and Youth C
and had started to argue about the game they were playing. Staff 1
reported he provided verbal redirection to all the youth about no
horseplaying and to focus on the game they were playing. He
reported Youth A told Youth B he was going “pants” him, meaning he
was going to pull Youth B’s pants down as a joke. Staff 1 reported
Youth B, in retaliation, pulled down Youth A’s pants. He reported
Youth A’s pants were down for a few seconds and he verbally
redirected Youth A and Youth B. Staff 1 reported Youth C attempted
to get involve in the situation and Staff 1 used verbal redirection.
During the time he was redirecting Youth C, Youth B attempted to put
Youth A’s jacket into the ceiling tile in the room. He reported when
that occurred, he brought all the youth back to the unit. Staff 1
reported the situation lasted not even five minutes before all the
youth were brought back to the unit. He reported Youth A, Youth B,
and Youth C received zeros on the point system due to inappropriate
boundaries and horseplay. Staff 1 reported it was documented within
the shift summary for all three youth that they each needed verbal
redirection for boundaries a few times. He reported he was not aware
that he needed to complete an incident report and did not tell anyone
in specific about the situation because it appeared to be just
horseplay.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on June
10, 2024. Supervisor reported Youth A disclosed the concerns of
Youth B and Youth C bullying him and Staff 1 not intervening. She
reported she talk with Staff 1 about the situation, and he
acknowledged Youth B did pull down Youth A’s pants as a means of
bullying him. Supervisor reported Staff 1 stated Youth A started the
situation by telling Youth B that he was going to “pants” him and in
retaliation, Youth B was the one to pull down Youth A’s pants first.
She reported Staff 1 stated he redirected and took responsibility of
not completing the incident report.
Documents Reviewed:
- Incident Report dated June 7, 2024- Incident report was
completed by Supervisor and was consistent with
Supervisor’s interview.
- Facility Behavior Management Policy with most recent
revision date of July 13, 2023- Staff 1 followed this policy as
noted within his interview as he verbally de-escalated the
3

situation and brought the youth back into the unit when
behaviors began to escalate.
- Staff 1’s Personnel File- Staff 1 has been employed at the
facility since September 2023. There were two disciplinary
actions noted within his file that noted concerns of Staff 1
speeding in the agency vehicle and being distracted on the
computer when supposed to be supervising the youth within
the classroom. Staff 1 is in compliance with required trainings
and complete behavior management trainings on October 16,
2023.
- Facility Shift Summary dated June 6, 2024- Within the shift
summary notes it is documented Youth A, Youth B, and Youth
C were provided a zero in points due to needing a few
redirections for boundaries.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there was not enough
information to support a rule violation as Staff 1 reported he did
intervene within the situation. Youth B and Youth C deny anything
occurred. There was no video recording of the incident.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Title required.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
Description assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff were present and did not make a CPS referral regarding the
sexual assault.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor, Administrator 1, and Administrator 2 were all
interviewed face to face separately at the facility on June 10,
2024. Supervisor reported when Youth A disclosed the situation to
her, she made sure to complete an internal incident report. She
reported she then discussed the situation with Administrator 1 and
Administrator 2. Supervisor, Administrator 1 and Administrator 2
individually reported that the situation reported did not arise to the
level of abuse and neglect as it appeared Youth A, Youth B and
Youth C were horseplaying with one another. Staff 1 was provided
verbal coaching from Supervisor about the need to complete an
internal incident report.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 10,
2024. Staff 1 reported Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were
4

horseplaying with one another on June 6, 2024. He reported he
provided verbal redirection of the situation and brought the youth
back to the unit within five minutes of the situation occurring. Staff 1
reported there was no concern sexual abuse happening and reported
Youth A’s pants were down for less than two seconds. He reported
he did not have a concern of abuse or neglect at the time of the
incident. Staff 1 reported he did not feel the incident arose to the
level that an internal incident report needed to be completed as there
was no complaints made to him from any of the youth about the
situation.
Documents Reviewed:
- Incident Report dated June 7, 2024- Incident report was
completed by Supervisor and was consistent with
Supervisor’s interview.
- Staff 1’s Personnel File- Staff received mandated reporting
training and Identifying and Responding to Child Abuse and
Neglect training on September 14, 2023.
- Facility Incident Reporting and Administrative Response
Procedure with most recent revision date of August 11,
2023- Policy notes incident reports need to be completed
when there are serious events that took place such as serious
physical, verbal or written threats, life threatening events,
minor assault and/or intentional injury, etc. This policy notes if
a staff has heard or see concerns of abuse or neglect
occurring to a youth at the facility, they are to follow mandated
reported protocols and make a call to centralized intake.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews it was
determined the allegations did not arise to the level of abuse or
neglect. It is believed there was concerns of miss communication
that Staff 1 did not complete a “report” meaning an internal
incident report.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered to make sure all facility staff are
trained in internal incident reporting and when a report rises to the
level of abuse/neglect reporting.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
June 27, 2024
